title: Creole Onion Soup Requires:  This recipe calls for the French bread to be spread with “Creole Butter.”  The recipe for which is in the “Miscellaneous > Odds and Ends” folder.  However, consider this as optional although it’s a nice touch.
ingredients: ¼ cup smoked ham drippings; or, bacon drippings
7½ ounces smoked ham, trimmed and coarsely chopped (approximately 1½ cups)
1 tablespoon firmly packed light brown sugar
½ teaspoon dried thyme leaves, crumbled
Oven-toasted French bread cut in slices
instructions: Melt the ham, or bacon, drippings with the butter in a heavy large pot over medium-low heat.  Add the onions and cook until its golden, stirring occasionally, about 30 minutes.

Reduce the heat to low.  Stir in the flour and cook for 5 minutes but do not let it brown.  Add the ham, lemon juice, sugar, paprika, pepper, thyme, cayenne, allspice, cloves, mace, and hot pepper sauce and cook for 5 minutes to blend the flavors, stirring occasionally.  Pour in the broth and wine.  Now increase the heat and bring the mixture to a simmer.  Cover partially (leave the cover slightly skewed) and simmer for 45 minutes.

Remove the soup from the heat and allow it to cool enough to work with.  Purée in a food processor or blender in batches, pulsing to obtain a slightly grainy texture.  Return the purée to the same pot, blend in the cream and cook over medium-low heat until thick, about 20 minutes.

Add the Cognac and cook for 5 minutes.  Adjust the seasoning with salt and hot pepper sauce to taste.  Spread the toasted French bread with the Creole Butter.  Ladle the soup into bowls, top each bowl with a slice of French bread and serve.
Source:  An Onion Sampler by Edena Sheldon, Bon Appétit, January 1985.
